factoid: Rostóv went to the English Hotel around ten o’clock.
Rostóv went straight from the theater to the English Hotel.
Rostóv had been with his family and Denisov at the theater.
Rostóv was shown to the best room at the English Hotel.
Dólokhov had taken the best room for that evening.
Twenty men were gathered round a table where Dólokhov sat between two candles.
There was a pile of gold and paper money on the table.
Dólokhov was keeping the bank.
Rostóv had not seen Dólokhov since Dólokhov's proposal and Sonia's refusal.
Rostóv felt uncomfortable at the thought of how they would meet.
Dólokhov's clear, cold glance met Rostóv as soon as Rostóv entered the door.
Dólokhov had long expected Rostóv.
Dólokhov said, "It's a long time since we met."
Dólokhov said, "Thanks for coming."
Dólokhov said, "I'll just finish dealing, and then Ilyúshka will come with his chorus."
Rostóv said, "I called once or twice at your house."
Dólokhov made no reply to Rostóv.
Dólokhov said, "You may punt."
Rostóv recalled a strange conversation he had once had with Dólokhov.
Dólokhov had said, "None but fools trust to luck in play."
Dólokhov asked, "Or are you afraid to play with me?"
Rostóv saw in Dólokhov the mood he had shown at the club dinner and at other times.
Rostóv felt ill at ease.
Rostóv tried but failed to find a joke to reply to Dólokhov's words.

Dólokhov, looking straight in Rostóv's face, said slowly and deliberately so that everyone could hear: "Do you remember we had a talk about cards... 'He's a fool who trusts to luck, one should make certain,' and I want to try."
Rostóv asked himself, "To try his luck or the certainty?"
Dólokhov said, "Well, you'd better not play."
Dólokhov sprang a new pack of cards and said, "Bank, gentlemen!"
Dólokhov moved the money forward and prepared to deal.
Rostóv sat down by Dólokhov's side and at first did not play.
Dólokhov kept glancing at Rostóv.
Dólokhov asked, "Why don't you play?"
Rostóv said, "I have no money with me."
Dólokhov said, "I'll trust you."
Rostóv staked five rubles on a card and lost.
Rostóv staked again and again lost.
Dólokhov beat ten cards of Rostóv's run.
Dólokhov said, "Gentlemen, please place your money on the cards or I may get muddled in the reckoning."
One of the players said he hoped he might be trusted.
Dólokhov replied, "Yes, you might, but I am afraid of getting the accounts mixed. So I ask you to put the money on your cards."
Dólokhov added, "Don't stint yourself, we’ll settle afterwards."
The game continued; a waiter kept handing round champagne.
All Rostóv's cards were beaten and he had eight hundred rubles scored up against him.
Rostóv wrote "800 rubles" on a card.
While the waiter filled his glass, Rostóv changed his mind and altered it to his usual stake of twenty rubles.
Dólokhov said, "Leave it."
Dólokhov said, "You'll win it back all the sooner."
Dólokhov said, "I lose to the others but win from you."
Dólokhov asked, "Or are you afraid of me?"
